title: When will Pierre Nkurunziza cease to be president of Burundi?
preds: I doubt anything will happen in the next week.

Burundian President Pierre Nkurunziza has launched a campaign to promote a referendum to change the constitution that could see him rule until 2034.
http://www.africareview.com/news/Burundi-president-wishes-to-extend-rule/979180-4226760-aigpar/index.html
Unless he decides to apply for the open seat in Zimbabwe....

Burundi president goes cycling with armed convoy
http://www.africanews.com/2017/09/22/photos-burundi-president-goes-cycling-with-armed-convoy//
It only takes one bullet, but not much going on there at the moment.
Shifting to 100 because Burundi hasn't been experiencing unrest and four months is a very short time to depose a president.

The movement “Halte au Troisième Mandat” [Halt to the Third Term], a collective of Civil Society Organizations campaigning against President Nkurunziza’s “unconstitutional” third term, has launched this Sunday 26 March a programme of education to active non-violence to help actors overcome fear that the movement says resulted from repression.
http://www.iwacu-burundi.org/englishnews/movement-against-president-nkurunzizas-third-term-goes-non-violent/ Motion to file complaints to ICC against Burundi government gains momentum
http://www.iwacu-burundi.org/englishnews/motion-to-file-complaints-to-icc-against-burundi-government-gains-momentum/

Burundi's environment minister shot dead in Bujumbura Emmanuel Niyonkuru becomes first serving government minister to be killed since political instability began in 2015.
http://www.aljazeera.com/topics/country/burundi.html

Rights groups urge UN sanctions for Burundi officials
http://www.news24.com/Africa/News/rights-groups-urge-un-sanctions-for-burundi-officials-20170308

The situation in Burundi, while still unpleasant, has calmed down dramatically compared with the unrest of last year. The country seems to have ended up as a fairly standard dictatorship where the population isn't particularly happy and a spark could set off more protests and riots, but where security forces have a good handle on day to day problems.

Focus now seems to be on 2020 elections:
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-burundi-politics-idUSKBN15U2KX

More than 370,000 refugees have fled Burundi since April 2015, when the country’s president Pierre Nkurunziza announced he was running for a third presidential term. Nkurunziza’s announcement sparked widespread protests and have led to clashes between security forces and anti-government activists.
http://europe.newsweek.com/burundian-refugees-tanzania-pierre-nkurunziza-554139?rm=eu

"Mass presidential pardon for quarter of prisoners in Burundi"
"..authorities aim to free some 2,500 spaces ...for more political inmates"
http://www.france24.com/en/20170124-burundi-release-one-quarter-prison-population-nkurunziza-jails

Burundi authorities have arrested six people in connection with the murder of the country’s environment minister, the prosecutor-general has said. Emmanuel Niyonkuru, 54, the water, environment and planning minister, was shot dead shortly after midnight on New Years Eve in the most high-profile killing since Burundi’s political crisis began nearly two years ago.
http://www.africanews.com/2017/01/08/burundi-arrests-six-people-over-ministers-killing/
At this time looks like assassination is the only way he goes, so odds on this are probably quite low.
wants to hang on to power, but the country is unstable so maybe

Burundi president's spokesperson escapes assassination attempt
http://www.africanews.com/2016/11/29/burundi-president-s-spokesperson-escapes-assassination-attempt/ Might not live very long in 2017.
If he eliminates term limits it puts him in a stronger position.

It looks like a main opposition leader has decided to cut a deal with Nkurunziza (Agathon Rwasa: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agathon_Rwasa), out of fear of his life and that of his followers. (the article is in French) http://www.burundidaily.net/2016/11/01/choisir-de-composer-avec-le-regime-autoritaire-de-pierre-nkurunziza-cette-strategie-dagathon-rwasa-va-t-elle-payer/ Nkurunziza seems to be in complete control right now

"One scientific study of 178 nations rated Burundi's population as having the lowest satisfaction with life in the world. As a result of deep poverty, Burundi is dependent on foreign aid." https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burundi#Economy
Tragically, things are not much worse under Nkurunziza than they always have been, and it's hard to see how things will ever improve for the citizens of Burundi. Being small and resource poor, international concern is limited and foreign aid is well short of what it should be. 
A coup attempt failed in 2015 and there are no signs that one could succeed in the near future. I suppose someone with a death wish might assassinate the president - that's what we're really forecasting, I think - but I suspect most downtrodden citizens would just settle for slightly better governance from the mob they've got. There doesn't appear to be a solid enough political alternative to risk civil war. It's safer just to leave.

Updating to reflect news (1) that Burundi is withdrawing from the International Criminal Court (was investigating likely governnment criminal activities) and confirming rationale from previous forecast
http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/346445 1: http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/africa/gambia-international-criminal-court-hague-yahya-jammeh-south-africa-burundi-a7380516.html

Burundi's media vacuum
How is Burundi's media crackdown adding to an already volatile situation that threatens another civil war?
http://www.aljazeera.com/programmes/listeningpost/2016/10/burundi-media-vacuum-161009091618915.html Former army officer and family killed in grenade attack in Burundi crisis
http://www.standardmedia.co.ke/article/2000216120/former-army-officer-and-family-killed-in-grenade-attack-in-burundi-crisis Once again I find myself pressed by GJ's demand for a date. The exact time when Burundi will fall into civil war is hard to predict, because there is already low level conflict. How long is a piece of string? When will the violence escalate into all out war? A few months probably, but it could take a year. And Pierre could survive for as long as 2 years max.

By banning UN investigators he continues to maintain his power and limit support for any remaining opposition.
http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/world/burundi-bans-three-un-human-rights-investigators/3195622.html

UN warns against risk of genocide in Burundi
http://www.presstv.ir/Detail/2016/09/20/485613/UN-Burundi-violence-genocide Brussels said on March 14 it was suspending direct financial support to the government, affecting a package worth about 432 million euros ($480 million) for 2014 to 2020
http://www.africanews.com/2016/09/30/eu-extends-sanctions-against-burundian-quartet-till-october-2017/ Unfortunately who knows how long he can survive even with the aid cut? He could fall in months, or take years. Sanctions are usually slow to take effect.

There's a great deal of instability in the country. However, Nkurunziza is likely to remain president as the opposition is too fragmented to present a viable option. The history of ethnic tensions in the region presents a clear security dilemma to the public and other actors, as further challenge to Nkurunziza may spiral into ethnic violence. See: https://www.dandc.eu/en/article/tensions-are-growing-and-violence-increasing-within-burundis-security-forces
Looking less likely in short term, assassination most likely cause.

Burindian politics are very volatile. Given the contestations of Nkurunziza's third term both internally and abroad, there is a certain probability that he will not finish his current presidential term.
Updating; opposition gone, quiet or killed...

The forecast was made on four factors, Nkurunziza's profile, country economy, internal opposition and international influence. The incumbent president clearly did not wish to relinquish power, however, BBC and UN profiles did not portray him as an out of control mad crazed dictator, although some of his critics probably would, and, critically, not as someone who is beyond compromising [1&2]. BBC described  Burundi as one of the world's poorest nations, and EU was considering to impose more sanctions following the failure of talks to end a political crisis [4]. Internal organised opposition was not considered to be strong, as evidenced by the failure of the coup and the fact that many have fled the country (did not believe that they stood a chance in overthrowing Nkurunziza ?). It appeared that although the situation was not volatile at present, a deteriorating economy will quickly stir unrest and the international community would be even more unsympathetic. Burundi was receiving aid from the EU, and although China seemed to have wanted to earn a right to play in the country, there was not much in the news of current involvement. On balance, a high probability was assigned to Nkurunziza making it beyond 2018, especially as poor economic conditions do not immediately and necessarily coalesce into successful coups. Moreover, Nkurunziza might comprise to some extend to ease tensions and get the exports going. The caveat being that forecasts beyond a year are not generally easy.  [1] http://www.irinnews.org/analysis/2016/03/02/burundi-power-struggle-outlasts-diplomatic-flurry
[2] http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-32490645
[3] http://www.irinnews.org/analysis/2016/02/12/how-burundi%E2%80%99s-political-crisis-has-crippled-its-economy
[4] http://www.reuters.com/article/us-burundi-politics-eu-idUSKCN0VO0XC

"Burundi could resort to import restrictions amid a clampdown on black market currency dealers whom it partly blames for a sharp drop in the value of the local currency against the dollar.The country has already imposed restrictions on food exports to Rwanda in a bid to keep inflation down — it is currently at three per cent — in the face of a looming drought. About 15 foreign exchange bureaus have been closed and a dozen money lenders arrested for violating foreign exchange laws, according to police spokesman Pierre Nkurikiye.“There is some kind of speculation that has led to the fluctuation. When there is a shortage of foreign-exchange reserves, we need as a country to adjust our needs. We cannot import if we don’t have foreign currency,” Audace Niyonzima, the director of research and statistics at the Burundi Central Bank said. The Burundi franc has over the past one month lost 34 per cent of its value to trade at Bf2,700 to the dollar, down from Bf1,800 units to the greenback.As of Friday, the official exchange rate was Bf1,670 to the dollar but the black market was offering Bf2,400 to the dollar.Despite the actions on the black market, the government views the depreciation as the impact of aid withheld from the country by the European Union in the wake of President Pierre Nkurunziza’s controversial bid for a third term in office last year.  "
http://www.theeastafrican.co.ke/business/Burundi-clamps-down-on-forex-black-market/2560-3351646-ry0pia/index.html
Moderating a little as time passes.

Nkurunziza is young and early in a five year term. He has survived one coup attempt and he has the support of the rural population. It will take an armed victory or assassination to remove him prior to another election. The minority Tutsis that control the military have strong motivation for Nkurunziza to stay in power even though he is mixed heritage Hutu and Tutsis.

After the initial attempt of a coup in 2015 the President has consolidated his power.   For the most part is seems his opposition has fled, been arrested or killed. He currently appears to have the support of China (1) and there now seems a possibility that he will attempt to abolish "term limits" (2).     While this may activate more opposition and resistance, the next Presidential election would not be until around 2020 so would not anticipate weakening of his power before January 2018.
1:  http://allafrica.com/stories/201608260804.html
2: http://www.businessinsider.com/burundis-government-might-scrap-presidential-term-limits-2016-8
V high level guess from synopsis Friends, options and resources will run out.

1. Burundi is isolated regionally. Rwanda is hostile. Burundi's border restrictions with Rwanda likely to provoke EAC sanctions; deepening isolation heightens civil war risks
http://www.janes.com/article/62960/burundi-s-border-restrictions-with-rwanda-likely-to-provoke-eac-sanctions-deepening-isolation-heightens-civil-war-risks 2. EU and USA have imposed sanctions. The EU sanctions in particular are problematic for a country that has little in the way of exports. "Burundi exports 26% of local produce to the EU, with Belgium-Luxembourg raking in $47.8-million of the $148-million worth of Burundi’s exports in 2014 compared with $733-million spent on imports, according to available statistics. "
http://mg.co.za/article/2016-07-27-00-bid-to-block-burundi-from-european-union-trade-pact-with-other-east-african-countries/
https://www.federalregister.gov/articles/2016/04/06/2016-07851/burundi-sanctions-regulations 3. The army is half and half Tutu and Hutsi.  Burundi: Tutsi army officers on missions abroad choose to defect instead of returning home
http://cnared.info/wordpress/burundi-tutsi-army-officers-on-missions-abroad-choose-to-defect-instead-of-returning-home/ 4.In 2014, popular demonstrations forced the long-time ruler of Burkina Faso, Blaise Compaoré, to abandon plans to extend his time in office. 
http://dailysignal.com/2016/08/15/violence-in-burundi-highlights-the-fragility-of-democracy-in-africa/ Faced with sanctions, internal opposition and a divided army, he won't last until 2018. But when will he fall is a more difficult question. Sanctions take months or a year to take full effect, so he won't be removed in the next couple of months, but 2 years is unlikely for a regime attacked on all fronts. Too many enemies, no friends.
Sounds like a candidate for assassination.
